text: Effect of nitrogen and phosphorus addition on leaf nutrient concentrationsand nutrient resorption efficiency of two dominant alpine grass species
LIU Yalan1,23,LILei1,2\*,LI Xiangyi1,2,YUE Zewei1,2,3,LIUB4

Abstract: Nitrogen $\mathrm { ( N ) }$ and phosphorus $( \mathrm { P } )$ are two essential nutrients that determine plant growth and many nutrient cycling processes. Increasing $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ deposition is an important driver of ecosystem changes. However, in contrast to numerous studies about the impacts of nutrient addition on forests and temperate grasslands, how plant foliar stoichiometry and nutrient resorption respond to $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { \Delta P }$ addition in alpine grasslands is poorly understood. Therefore, we conducted an $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { \bf P }$ addition experiment (involving control, N addition, $\mathrm { \Delta P }$ addition, and $\mathrm { \Delta N + P }$ addition) in an alpine grassland on Kunlun Mountains (Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region，China) in 2016 and 2017 to investigate the changes in leaf nutrient concentrations (i.e., leaf N, Leaf ${ \mathrm { l } } _ { 3 } ^ { \mathrm { ~ ~ } }$ and leaf N:P ratio) and nutrient resorption efficiency of Seripbidium rbodantbum and Stipa capillata, which are dominant species in this grassland.Results showed that $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition has significant effects on soil inorganic $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ ${ ( \mathrm { N O } _ { 3 } } ^ { - } { - } \mathrm { N }$ and $\mathrm { N H _ { 4 } ^ { + } { - } N }$ ）and leaf N of both species in the study periods. Compared with green leaves, leaf nutrient concentrations and nutrient resorption eficiency in senesced leaves of $S _ { \cdot }$ ，rbodantbum was more sensitive to $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition,whereas $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition influenced leaf N and leaf N:P ratio in green and senesced leaves of $S$ 、capillata.N addition did not influence $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ resorption efficiency of the two species. $\mathrm { \Delta P }$ addition and $\mathrm { { N + P } }$ addition significantly improved leaf $\mathrm { \Delta P }$ and had a negative effect on $\mathrm { \bf P }$ resorption eficiency of the two species in the study period. These influences on plants can be explained by increasing $\mathrm { \bf P }$ availability. The present results illustrated that the two species are more sensitive to $\mathrm { \Delta P }$ addition than $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition,which implies that $\mathrm { \Delta P }$ is the major limiting factor in the studied alpine grassland ecosystem.In addition,an interactive effect of $\mathrm { { N + P } }$ addition was only discernable with respect to soil availability,but did not affect plants. Therefore, exploring how nutrient characteristics and resorption response to $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ addition in the alpine grassand is important to understand nutrient use strategy of plants in terrestrial ecosystems.
Keywords: leaf nutrientconcentration; nutrient resorptioneficiency; leaf N:Pratio;Naddition; Paddition;Seripbdium rbodantbum,Stipacapillata
1 Introduction

Nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) are two important nutrients for plant growth (Zhang et al., 2017). Theimbalanced $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ deposition induced by human activities,such as fertilization and fossil fuel combustion (Delonge et al., 2Oo8),affects the primary production of plants and profoundly influences the structure and function of ecosystems (Sardans et al.，2012; Chen et al.,2015; Monuca et al.，2O21). To explore how nutrient cycling between plants and soil in different ecosystems responds to nutrient deposition, researchers conducted many experimental studies (Chen et al., 2015; Li et al., 2016). For example, Tian and Niu (2015) reported that excessive N addition influences nutrient cycling between plants and soil and intensifies soil acidification in a global meta-analysis. Yang (2018） established an experiment of external $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ addition in a subtropical forest and concluded that P addition improves leaf P concentration but has no effect on P resorption eficiency (PRE). These studies help explain the impacts of nutrient addition on plant growth and nutrient cycling processes in ecosystems (Chen et al., 2015; Tian and Niu, 2015).

Leaf nutrient concentrations are the most vital indicators of plant growth (Yang, 2018; Xu et al., 2021)and are generally positively correlated with soil nutrient availability when the ecosystem is limited by nutrient resources (Garnier, 1998). They are also correlated with internal nutrient resorption, which is a critical nutrient conservation strategy for plants (Killingbeck,1996; Vergutz et al.,2012). Nutrient resorption efciency (NuRE) is used to quantify nutrient resorption in plants (Wright and Westoby, 2003; Chen et al., 2015). Generally, $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ concentration less than $0 . 5 ~ \mathrm { m g / g }$ in senesced leaves denotes a high PRE,and N concentration higher than $7 . 0 ~ \mathrm { m g / g }$ in senesced leaves signifies a low N resorption efficiency (NRE) (Killingbeck，1996). Furthermore， negative relationships between NuRE and leaf nutrient concentrations have been widely reported (Chen et al.,2012; Lü et al.，2013; Zheng et al., 2020).Lu et al. (2013) demonstrated that NRE of six sub-arctic bog species decreases following four years of experimental $\mathsf { N }$ addition. However, positive and neutral relationships between NuRE and leaf nutrient concentrations have also been revealed (Aerts,1996; Chen et al., 2015). For example, a meta-analysis conducted by Yuan and Chen et al. (2O15） showed that NuRE does not change with nutrient addition,possibly because nutrient concentrations in plants depend more on external nutrient supply rather than internal resorption in some ecosystems. This finding difers from that of Yang (2O18),who found that approximately $50 \%$ of green leaf nutrients are resorbed from senesced leaves. These contradictory results suggest that further studies on NuRE response to nutrient addition are needed to understand nutrient cycling in terrestrial ecosystems.

Ecological stoichiometric characteristics are also important indices of plant growth. From freshwater to terrestrial ecosystems，N:P ratio is widely employed to elucidate nutrient limitations (Güsewell, 2004; Elser et al., 2007; Jin et al., 2020).Koerselman and Meuleman (1996) reported that plants in a wetland ecosystem are limited by P when N:P ratio is higher than 16 and limited by $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ when the ratio is lower than 14. Zhang et al. (2Oo4) revealed that an N:P ratio lower than 21 signifies N limitation while a ratio higher than 23 suggests P limitation in a steppe ecosystem in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China. These results indicate that N:P ratio is determined by ecosystem types and plant species (Verterink et al., 2O0l; Menge and Field, 2007). However, recent studies about N:P ratio have tended to focus on green leaves while neglecting senesced leaves (Liu et al., 2013; Zhang et al.,2017). Persson et al. (2010) concluded that N:P ratios in green leaves are more stable than those in senesced leaves due to nutrient resorption (Chen et al.，2O15). Therefore，understanding how increasing $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ addition influences N:P ratio in senesced leaves is also important.

Alpine grassland is a typical terrestrial ecosystem,and numerous studies have reported that this ecosystem is limited by N or co-limited by N and P (Elser et al.,2007; Xu et al.,2014; Zhang et al., 2021).Many researchers have ilustrated that long-term nutrient deposition accelerates nutrient cycling between plants and soil with concomitant impact on nutrient limitation. For example, Tian and Niu (2015) showed that N addition decreases soil $\mathfrak { p H }$ but increases P desorption. Penuelas et al. (2013） suggested that long-term $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ inputs shift ecosystem limitation from N to P. However, our understanding of nutrient cycling responses to external nutrient inputs in alpine grasslands is limited (Sardans et al.,2012). In addition, N and $\mathrm { \bf P }$ are believed to be linked tightly in nutrient cycle processes,and the interactive effects of these nutrients appear to difer from the effect of $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ or $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ addition alone (Peng et al.,2019).Moreover, the interactive influence of the addition of these major nutrients in alpine grasslands is less well understood. Hence, in order to determine how increasing N and $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ deposition influences terrestrial ecosystems, it is necessary to explore the effects of N and $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ addition,as well as the combination of $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and P, on leaf nutrient concentrations and nutrient resorption efficiency in alpine grasslands.

Here,we conducted an experiment (involving control, N addition, P addition, and $\mathrm { \Delta N + P }$ addition) and sampled two dominant alpine grass species (i.e., Seriphidium rhodanthum and Stipa capillata) in an alpine grassland on Kunlun Mountains, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region of China in 2016 and 2017. This study aims to: (1) explore the responses of leaf N,leaf P, N:Pratio,and NuRE to external nutrient addition in this alpine grassland; (2） assess the interactive effect of these nutrients on this ecosystem; and (3） evaluate whether $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ addition alleviates or enhances limitation in this alpine ecosystem.
2 Materialsand methods
2.1Study area and experimental design

This study was conducted in an alpine grassland ( $( 3 6 ^ { \circ } 0 8 ^ { \prime } 0 3 ^ { \prime \prime } \mathrm { N }$ ， $8 1 ^ { \circ } 0 6 ^ { \prime } 3 3 ^ { \prime \prime } \mathrm { E }$ ：， $3 1 0 0 \mathrm { ~ m ~ }$ a.s.l.） on Kunlun Mountains, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region of China in 2016 and 2017. The topographic conditions in this region were uniform. The annual mean air temperature was approximately $5 . 2 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ in 2016 and $3 . 8 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ in 2017 (Fig.1). The monthly mean temperature ranged from $- 5 . 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ in February to $1 5 . 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ in July in 2016 and from $- 8 . 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ in January to $1 2 . 6 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ in July in 2017. The total precipitation was $4 8 2 \mathrm { m m }$ in 2016 and $5 6 1 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ in 2017,with most occurring from May to October. S. rhodanthum and S. capilata are the two dominant grass species in this region. S.capillata covers more than $70 \%$ of the total aboveground biomass,and S. rhodanthum accounts for more than $20 \%$

text: This study simulated $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { \bf P }$ addition via four treatments: control (no fertilization), $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition $( 1 6 ~ \mathrm { g } ~ \mathrm { N } / ( \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } { \cdot } \mathrm { a } ) )$ ， $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ addition $( 3 \mathrm { ~ g ~ P / ( m } ^ { 2 } { \cdot } \mathrm { a } ) )$ ,and $\mathrm { N + P }$ addition ( $( 1 6 ~ \mathrm { g } ~ \mathrm { N } / ( \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } { \cdot } \mathrm { a } )$ and $3 \mathrm { ~ g ~ P / ( m } ^ { 2 } { \cdot } \mathrm { a } ) )$ . The nutrient addition protocol was based on an extant study on the Bayanbulak alpine grassands of Xinjiang, China (Yue et al., 2016). Sixteen $2 \mathrm { m } { \times } 3 \mathrm { m }$ plots were established (four replicates for each treatment) for each species. All plots were separated by at least $1 \mathrm { ~ m ~ }$ ，and each plot was randomly arranged. In late April, monobasic potassium phosphate and urea were mixed with soil from the test plots and spread evenly on the surface of the soil.
2.2Sampling and measurements

Plant and soil collection was carried out following the methods of Lü et al. (2O13) with minor modifications. One hundred leaves (fully expanded) of $S .$ capillata and S. rhodanthum with similar size,respectively,were chosen from the center of each plot.Half of the samples were collcted as the green group in August of both years,and the rest samples were marked and collected as the senesced group in October of both years. All samples were dried at $7 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ for $4 8 \mathrm { h }$ ,milled,and sieved (1 mm mesh) for chemical property determination. Soil samples were collected in mid-August of 2016 and 2017. Five points were selected in each plot, and soil samples were collected using a soil drilling sampler with a diameter of $5 \ \mathrm { c m }$ . All soil samples were completely mixed and passed through a 2-mm mesh to eliminate roots and other debris.

Leaf $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ concentration was analyzed using an auto elemental analyzer (Vario EL II, Elementar Analysensysteme GmbH,Hanau,Germany).Leaf $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ concentration was measured by Mo-Sb colorimetric method after $\mathrm { H } _ { 2 } \mathrm { S O } _ { 4 } \mathrm { + H C l O } _ { 4 }$ digestion. Soil inorganic $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ $( \mathsf { N O } _ { 3 } ^ { - } - \mathsf { N }$ and $\mathrm { N H _ { 4 } ^ { + } { - } N }$ was determined by the Kjeldahl method using an Alpkem autoanalyzer (FIAstar 5Oo0,Foss Tecator, Denmark). Soil available P was determined by Mo-Sb colorimetric method (Chen et al.,2015).
2.3 Calculation of nutrient resorption efficiency (NuRE)
In this study, we calculated NuRE (i.e., PRE and NRE) based on nutrient concentrations in leaves (Lü et al., 2013).

$$
\mathrm { N u R E \ ( \% ) { = } ( ( N u t r i e n t _ { g r e e n } { - } N u t r i e n t _ { s e n e s c e d } ) / N u t r i e n t _ { g r e e n } ) } { \times } 1 0 0 \% ,
$$
where Nutrientgreen is the nutrient concentration in green leaves $\left( \mathrm { m g / g } \right)$ and Nutrientsenesced is the nutrient concentration in senesced leaves $( \mathrm { m g / g } )$
2.4 Statistical analysis

Linear mixed effect models were used to evaluate the effects of year, $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition, $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ addition, and $\mathsf { N } { + } \mathsf { P }$ addition on soil inorganic N,soil available P, leaf N,leaf P, leaf N:P ratio,NRE,PRE,and NRE:PRE ratio. We set year as a random factor to evaluate the effects of temperature, precipitation, and other meteorological factors on $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ concentrations in soil and plants.N addition，P addition, and $\mathsf { N } { + } \mathsf { P }$ addition were set as fixed factors to evaluate the effects of $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition, P addition，and the interactive effect of $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition and $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ addition on nutrient stoichiometric characteristics of soil and plants. One-way ANOVA was performed to test the influences of N addition, P addition, and $\mathsf { N } { + } \mathsf { P }$ addition on soil inorganic N, soil available P, leaf N, leaf P, leaf N:P ratio, NRE, PRE,and NRE:PRE ratio. An ANOVA post-hoc test, specifically the least significant diference method, was performed to determine differences between individual treatments.Pearson correlation analysis was conducted to determine the relationship between leaf nutrient concentrations and soil nutrient concentrations.R 4.0.4 software was used to perform all analyses, and $\scriptstyle P = 0 . 0 5$ was used to detect statistical significance.
3 Results
3.1 Soil inorganic N and available Pconcentrations

The random factor year showed a significant effect on soil inorganic $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and available P concentrations (Table 1). N addition significantly affected soil inorganic N but did not affect soil available P; P addition significantly affected soil available P but did not influence soil inorganic N. Moreover, $\mathrm { \Delta N + P }$ addition was only discernable with respect to soil available P. The effects of N addition and $\mathrm { \Delta N + P }$ addition on soil inorganic $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ were positive in both years (Fig. 2).A significant increase in soil available $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ was observed in both years in $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ addition and $\mathrm { \Delta N + P }$ addition treatments, and the highest values were observed following $\mathrm { \bf P }$ addition alone (Fig. 2).

text: 3.2Leaf nutrient concentrations and nutrient resorption efficiency $\mathbf { ( N u R E ) }$

The random factor year had significant effects on leaf N and leaf N:P ratio in green leaves and leaf $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ in senesced leaves of S. rhodanthum (Table 2). It significantly influenced leaf $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and leaf $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ in green and senesced leaves and leaf N:P ratio in senesced leaves of $S .$ capillata.N addition affected leaf $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and leaf N:P ratio in green and senesced leaves of S. capillata and senesced leaves of $S$ （号 rhodanthum.P addition also influenced leaf $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ and leaf N:P ratio in the two species, except green leaves of S. rhodanthum. N addition and $\mathrm { \Delta N + P }$ addition increased leaf $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ in S. capillata in both years (Fig. 3). P addition and $\mathrm { \Delta N + P }$ addition increased leaf P in the two species.However, leaf P did not change in either of the two species following $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition,and leaf N also did not change in response to $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ addition.An interactive effect of $\mathrm { \Delta N + P }$ addition was only observed in senesced leaves of S. capillata (Table 3). N addition exerted positive effects on leaf N:P ratio in green and senesced leaves of $S .$ capillata (Fig. 4). N:P ratios in green and senesced leaves of the two species in $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ addition and $\mathrm { \Delta N + P }$ addition treatments were lower than that in control treatment. Moreover, leaf N:P ratio in S. capillata was higher than that in S. rhodanthum.

text: 3.3Relationship between leaf nutrient concentrations and soil nutrient concentrations

Green leaf $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ had a positive relationship with soil inorganic $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ for S. capillata but exhibited no relationship for S. rhodanthum (Table 5). Leaf $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ generally showed no relationship with soil available P. In both species,green leaf $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ had a positive relationship with soil available $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ and showed no relationship with soil inorganic N. Green leaf N:P ratio was negatively correlated with soil available P. In terms of senesced leaf N:P ratio in S. rhodanthum and S. capillata, it had a positive relationship with soil inorganic $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and a negative relationship with soil available $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ in the two years. Moreover, compared with S. rhodanthum, S. capillata was more sensitive to external nutrient addition, and both species were more sensitive to $\mathrm { \bf P }$ addition than N addition.

text: 4Discussion
4.1 Leaf nutrient concentrations

N addition had a positive effect on soil inorganic $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and leaf N, while $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ addition had a positive effect on soil available $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ and leaf $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ although leaf and soil nutrient concentrations showed significant differences between 2016 and 2017. These results are similar to what has been found in previous studies (e.g.,N addition increases soil inorganic N and P addition increases soil available $\mathrm { \bf P }$ and leaf P) (Xu and Timmer,1999; Yuan and Chen, 2015; Deng et al.,2016). Many studies have also reported positive relationships between leaf nutrient concentrations and soil nutrient concentrations (Chen et al.，2015；Huang et al.，2016;Li et al.，2016).Hence, the obvious differences of leaf nutrient concentrations in this study might be due to the different soil nutrient concentrations in the two years.We speculated that the reason for the differences of soil nutrient concentrations in both years might be caused by different precipitation amounts. Soil nutrient concentrations would increase with increasing precipitation (Yuan and Chen, 2Oo9； Zhao et al., 2017).For example, Zhao et al. (2017) reported that soil C and $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ concentrations increase with increasing precipitation gradient on the Tibetan Changtang Plateau, China. Brant and Chen (2015)

text: revealed that plant PRE decreases with increasing precipitation because soil $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ availability increases. However, following $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition and $\mathsf { N } { + } \mathsf { P }$ addition, leaf $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ of S. rhodanthum showed no changes except for senesced leaves in 2017. This may reflect delayed responses of the two species to nutrient addition (Bowman et al.,2006; Bai et al.,2010),or plants are insensitive to short-term N addition but could adjust physiological demand to utilize high available $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ during long-term nutrient addition (Chen et al.,2O15). Our results also showed that senesced leaves of $S .$ rhodanthum are more sensitive to N addition than green leaves, which resonates with the findings of Persson et al. (2010), who noted that green leaves of some plants are more stable than senesced leaves due to homeostatic regulation and nutrient resorption (Chen et al.,2O15). In our study, $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ concentrations in green and senesced leaves varied with $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ addition in both years. This result is similar to previous studies showing that green leaf $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ does not change with $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition but leaf $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ is significantly influenced by $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ addition in N-saturated ecosystems, implying P limitation (Yang, 2018; Xu et al., 2021).

For S. capillata, N addition and $\mathrm { \bf P }$ addition had significant effects on green leaf N:P ratio and senesced leaf N:P ratio, which implied that this species is sensitive to external nutrient addition and the nutrient use strategy of $S .$ capillata is different from that of S. rhodanthum.These results indicate that green leaf nutrient concentrations of $S .$ capillata depend more on direct absorption rather than resorption compared with those of S. rhodanthum. Killingbeck (1996) showed that plants have a high $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ use efficiency when $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ concentration in senesced leaves is lower than $0 . 5 \mathrm { m g / g }$ and a low $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ use efficiency when $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ concentration in senesced leaves is higher than $7 . 0 ~ \mathrm { m g / g }$ Our data revealed that $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ concentrations in green and senesced leaves of both species are $< 0 . 5 \ \mathrm { m g / g }$ which suggests that both species have a high $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ use efficiency.Furthermore,our data showed that the two species are more sensitive to $\mathrm { \bf P }$ addition than $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition and the degree of variations under $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ addition was greater than that under $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition. This finding is similar to previous studies. For instance,Bobbink（l991） reported that in a chalk grassland in Holland,leaf $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ concentrations increase to a greater extent than leaf N concentrations. This patern has also been reported in alpine tundra (Bowman et al.,1993) and other P-limited ecosystems (Sword et al.,2004; Gusewell, 2005; Ostertag，2O10). These results also suggest that nutrient addition would change leaf nutrient concentrations, which consequently facilitates litter decomposition and accelerates nutrient cycling between plants and soil (Zhang et al.,2Oo8). In addition, these results support the finding that the influence of nutrient addition depends on the experimental duration and species (Mayor et al., 2014). Chen et al. (2015) reported some differences between short-term and long-term results in terms of grass responses to nutrient addition. Tian and Niu (2015) suggested that long-term N addition intensifies soil acidification and increases P availability through P desorption (Wang et al., 2011).Therefore，more long-term studies are necessary to investigate how external nutrient addition influences nutrient cycling between plants and soil.
4.2 Nutrient resorption efficiency (NuRE)

N addition did not change NuRE of the two species in either year, which is similar to previous studies on ecosystems that are not limited by N (Huang et al.,2016; Long et al.,2016; Yang, 2018). This result suggests that leaf $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ of the two species in this alpine grassland ecosystem is more regulated by external $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition than internal resorption (Yang,2O18).Moreover, NRE:PRE ratio of the two species in $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition treatment was lower than that in control treatment (except S. rhodanthum in 2016),which implies that the two species have a high efficiency of $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ utilization. These results also support the hypothesis that $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ is not the major limiting element in the alpine grassland system.Paddition decreases PRE of S. capillata, similar to a previous study showing that PRE has a negative relationship with leaf P (Lüi et al., 2O13). Our data indicated that $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ addition in the two years not only changes P absorption directly but also influences the internal resorption of $S$ capillata.P inputs exert no influence on PRE of S. rhodanthum,which is consistent with the findings of Yuan and Chen (2015),who found that $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ addition increases $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ concentrations but has no effect on PRE of some plants in P-limited ecosystems.The possble reason might be that these plants cannot adjust nutrient characteristics quickly in response to environmental change. The two species (S. capillata and S. rhodanthum) demonstrated different strategic responses to $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ addition. These results confirmed that species is the dominant factor for nutrient dynamics (He et al., 2008). Hence, more further studies on plant responses to external nutrient addition are needed to predict community succession in alpine grasslands.

Many studies have explored how leaf N, N:P ratio, and NRE respond to $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition and how $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ cycling between plants and soil responds to $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ addition (Lawrence, 2001; Huang et al., 2016; Long et al.，2O16). However,researches concerning the interactive effects of $\mathsf { N }$ and $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ are limited. Previous experiments have shown that increasing N deposition could increase, decrease, or have no influence on leaf $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ and soil $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ concentrations and PRE via affecting phosphatase enzymes (Rodriguez and Fraga,1999; Marklein and Houlton,2012; Tian and Niu,2015).For example,in an old-growth boreal forest, Xu et al. (2021) reported that leaf $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ and other nutrients do not change with soil $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ concentrations though the long-term $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition increases leaf $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ in some extent compared to control treatment. However, Yang (2018) concluded that $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition does not change leaf $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ in P-limited tropical forests. In this study,we found that leaf $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ concentrations are not very responsive to $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition. The results of the linear mixed effect model showed that no interactive effect of N and $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ can be observed. These findings also support the conclusion that the effects of N addition on plant $\mathrm { \bf P }$ concentrations are minimal in a non-N limitation ecosystem (Chen et al., 2015; Yang,2018),and these results showed that plants could adjust leaf nutrient concentrations to adopt the change of ecosystem limitation (Jin et al.,2020).
4.3 Ecosystem limitation

Previous studies have explained that a high N:Pratio indicates that plants are limited byP, while a low N:P ratio signifies plants are limited by $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ (Chen et al., 2015; Zhang et al., 2017). Koerselman and Meuleman（1996） showed that the threshold values for $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { ~ \bf ~ P ~ }$ limitation are 14 and 16, respectively. N:P ratio in green or senesced leaves generally increases with $\mathsf { N }$ addition,and $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ becomes the major limiting factor subsequently; however, the ratio decreases with Paddition, and N will become the major limiting factor (Tilman, 1982). In our experiment, $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition improved green leaf N:P ratio of S. capillata from more than 16 in the control group to more than 2O and increased senesced leaf N:P ratio to more than 5O.P addition and $\mathrm { \Delta N + P }$ addition decreased the ratio to below 14 in both green and senesced leaves. The results also support that $S .$ capillata is limited by $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ rather than N. The responses of N:P ratio of $S$ ，rhodanthum to nutrient addition differed from those of $S$ （2号 capillata.Although the ratio in green and senesced leaves of $S .$ rhodanthum had different responses to external nutrient addition, the values were lower than 14 in the four treatments. This might be because S.rhodanthum hadhigher leaf $\mathrm { \bf P }$ concentrations and was insensitive to $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition.These results also showed that the critical N:P ratio for nutrient limitation is determined by species,and N:P ratio could not be the only indicator to show the limitation for plants.

As S. capillata represents more than $70 \%$ and $S .$ rhodanthum occupies more than $20 \%$ of the aboveground biomass in the study area, the limitation of the two species can be regarded as the limitation of this alpine grassand. According to the responses of leaf N,leaf P, leaf N:P ratio, NRE, PRE, and NRE:PRE to $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition and P addition for the two species,the ecosystem is limited by $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ rather than N. This result contradicts earlier research，which found that alpine grasslands are limited by $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ or $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { \bf ~ P } _ { \mathrm { \bf ~ m ~ } }$ ，which may be explained by the alleviation of $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ limitation of this ecosystem under long-term $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ deposition (Long et al., 2016). More studies are needed to strengthen our understanding of nutrient limitation in the context of long-term global nutrient deposition.
5 Conclusions

Our results showed that the alpine grassland on the Kunlun Mountains is not a N-limited ecosystem and the interactive effect of $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ and $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ is not evident. The responses of the two species (S. rhodanthum and S. capillata) to nutrient addition are species-specific. S. capillata is more sensitive to $\mathrm { \bf P }$ addition and has a higher $\mathrm { \bf ~ P }$ use efficiency than S.rhodanthum. Given that S.rhodanthum is insensitive to $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition, increasing $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition would support the growth of S. capillata. However, although $\mathrm { \Delta N }$ addition supports the growth of S. capillata, this alpine grassand is P-limited and S. capillata is mainly limited by P.Future studies should explore the responses of the two species to nutrient addition over a longer period.
